question: What does the cofactor equation predict about why some cancers respond to immunotherapy while others don't, and can VDAC1 state serve as a predictive biomarker for immunotherapy response? Consider: (1) VDAC1 oligomerization leaks mtDNA into the cytoplasm, activating cGAS-STING innate immune signaling. Cancer cells that successfully jam the gate (high f_HKII, high f_BclxL, high Chol/CL) prevent VDAC oligomerization and therefore prevent immune detection. Does gate-jamming predict immune cold tumors? (2) Could pharmacological gate-restoration (HK-II displacement + Bcl-xL inhibition) convert immune-cold tumors to immune-hot by forcing VDAC oligomerization and mtDNA release? (3) The checkpoint inhibitor paradox: PD-1/PD-L1 blockade works when the immune system can already see the tumor. If the tumor is invisible because VDAC never oligomerizes (no mtDNA leak, no cGAS-STING), checkpoint inhibitors have nothing to amplify. Prediction: gate-restoring drugs + checkpoint inhibitors should show synergy specifically in immune-cold tumors. (4) Can f_HKII occupancy or Chol/CL ratio measured from tumor biopsies predict which patients benefit from immunotherapy? (5) Does the cofactor equation explain why metabolically active tumors (high Warburg, high glycolysis) tend to be immune-cold — the same metabolic investment that jams the gate also prevents immune visibility?

gate.recommendation: Lab Gate PASSED with filter. 10/21 claims cleared. 11 filtered: 'Gate-restoring drugs (HK-II displacers + navitocla...' not feasible; 'f_HKII occupancy and Chol/CL ratio from tumor biop...' not feasible; 'Pharmacological gate-restoration (HK-II displaceme...' not feasible

hypotheses.prediction: IF HK-II is displaced from VDAC1 (via methyl jasmonate or clotrimazole) in immune-cold cancer cell lines with high baseline f_HKII (>0.6), THEN cytoplasmic mtDNA levels increase ≥3-fold within 6h, phospho-STING (Ser366) increases ≥2-fold by 12h, and IFN-β secretion increases ≥5-fold by 24h, compared to vehicle control.

IF a composite gate-jamming score (GJS = f_HKII × 0.4 + f_BclxL × 0.3 + [Chol/CL] × 0.3, normalized) is computed across ≥15 cancer cell lines, THEN GJS correlates inversely with basal cGAS-STING pathway activity (p-STING, ISG expression) with Spearman ρ ≤ −0.6 (p<0.01), and lines with GJS >0.7 show ≥80% concordance with immune-cold classification (low MHC-I, low CXCL10).

IF immune-cold syngeneic tumors (4T1 or B16F10, predicted high GJS) are treated with gate-restoring combination (HK-II displacer + Bcl-xL inhibitor) followed by anti-PD-1, THEN tumor growth inhibition shows synergy (combination index <0.7 by Bliss independence) with ≥50% tumor volume reduction vs. anti-PD-1 alone, while immune-hot tumors (MC38, predicted low GJS) show no additional benefit from gate-restoration beyond anti-PD-1 alone.

protocols.prediction: IF HK-II is displaced from VDAC1 (via methyl jasmonate or clotrimazole) in immune-cold cancer cell lines with high baseline f_HKII (>0.6), THEN cytoplasmic mtDNA levels increase ≥3-fold within 6h, phospho-STING (Ser366) increases ≥2-fold by 12h, and IFN-β secretion increases ≥5-fold by 24h, compared to vehicle control.
protocols.protocol: Use Panc-1 (pancreatic, immune-cold archetype, high HK-II/VDAC1) and A375 (melanoma, moderate HK-II) cell lines. Treat with methyl jasmonate (0.5-3 mM) or clotrimazole (10-50 μM) for 6/12/24h. Measure cytoplasmic mtDNA by qPCR after digitonin fractionation, p-STING by Western blot, IFN-β by ELISA, and VDAC1 oligomerization by EGS crosslinking + native PAGE. Include HK-II siRNA as genetic control. Timeline: 4 weeks.
readouts: ND5 mtDNA genes in cytoplasmic fraction)
native PAGE with EGS crosslinking (VDAC1 oligomers)
controls: DNase I cytoplasmic pre-treatment (confirms mtDNA dependency)
protocols.null_outcome: HK-II displacement does not increase cytoplasmic mtDNA or p-STING, or mtDNA increases but cGAS-STING remains silent, indicating the coupling is not through VDAC1 oligomerization.

protocols.prediction: IF a composite gate-jamming score (GJS = f_HKII × 0.4 + f_BclxL × 0.3 + [Chol/CL] × 0.3, normalized) is computed across ≥15 cancer cell lines, THEN GJS correlates inversely with basal cGAS-STING pathway activity (p-STING, ISG expression) with Spearman ρ ≤ −0.6 (p<0.01), and lines with GJS >0.7 show ≥80% concordance with immune-cold classification (low MHC-I, low CXCL10).
protocols.protocol: Select 15-20 cell lines spanning tumor types (e.g., Panc-1, MDA-MB-231, A549, HCT116, SK-MEL-28, MCF7, PC3, U87, HepG2, NCI-H460, B16F10, 4T1, CT26, MC38, LLC). Quantify HK-II:VDAC1 co-IP (f_HKII), Bcl-xL:VDAC1 co-IP (f_BclxL), mitochondrial cholesterol and cardiolipin by mass spectrometry. Simultaneously measure p-STING, ISG panel (qPCR: IFIT1, MX1, OAS1, ISG15), surface MHC-I (flow cytometry), CXCL10 (ELISA). Compute GJS, correlate. Timeline: 8 weeks.
controls: Recombinant IFN-β treatment (positive control for ISG induction capacity)
STING agonist diABZI (confirms pathway competence per line)
mitochondrial fraction purity verified by Tom20+/calreticulin−
protocols.expected_outcome: Strong inverse correlation between GJS and immune signaling metrics. Cell lines cluster into gate-jammed/immune-cold vs. gate-open/immune-hot groups. Pancreatic and certain lung lines show highest GJS; colorectal lines like MC38 show lowest.
protocols.null_outcome: No significant correlation between GJS and immune metrics, or high-GJS lines show active cGAS-STING, indicating gate-jamming is not the dominant determinant of immune visibility.

protocols.prediction: IF immune-cold syngeneic tumors (4T1 or B16F10, predicted high GJS) are treated with gate-restoring combination (HK-II displacer + Bcl-xL inhibitor) followed by anti-PD-1, THEN tumor growth inhibition shows synergy (combination index <0.7 by Bliss independence) with ≥50% tumor volume reduction vs. anti-PD-1 alone, while immune-hot tumors (MC38, predicted low GJS) show no additional benefit from gate-restoration beyond anti-PD-1 alone.
protocols.protocol: Implant 4T1 (immune-cold) and MC38 (immune-hot) tumors in BALB/c and C57BL/6 mice respectively (n=10/group). Groups: (1) vehicle, (2) gate-restoration combo (methyl jasmonate 100mg/kg IP + ABT-263/navitoclax 50mg/kg PO, days 5-12), (3) anti-PD-1 (200μg IP, days 8,11,14), (4) gate-restoration + anti-PD-1. Measure tumor volume q2d, sacrifice day 21 for TIL analysis (flow: CD8+, CD4+, NK), intratumoral cytokines (multiplex), and tumor mtDNA cytoplasmic fraction. Timeline: 10 weeks including breeding/acclimation.
readouts: qPCR cytoplasmic mtDNA from sorted tumor cells
controls: STING-KO host mice (to confirm cGAS-STING dependency)
heat-killed tumor cell vaccination (confirms antigenicity exists)
navitoclax alone (Bcl-xL inhibition without HK-II displacement)
protocols.expected_outcome: In 4T1: gate-restoration alone modestly slows growth; anti-PD-1 alone fails; combination produces dramatic regression with synergistic CI<0.7, increased CD8+ TILs, elevated intratumoral IFN-β. In MC38: anti-PD-1 alone effective; gate-restoration adds no benefit, confirming specificity to immune-cold context.
protocols.null_outcome: No synergy in 4T1 (combination no better than additive), or gate-restoration + anti-PD-1 works equally in MC38, indicating the mechanism is not specific to gate-jamming status.

final_claims.statement: High f_HKII occupancy stabilizes VDAC1 monomers, suppressing oligomerization-dependent mtDNA release and cGAS-STING activation, contributing to immune-cold phenotype.
final_claims.mechanism: HK-II binding to VDAC1 locks the channel in a metabolically favorable but oligomerization-incompetent conformation, preventing the mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization that releases mtDNA fragments.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Showing that HK-II knockdown in immune-cold tumor lines fails to increase cytoplasmic mtDNA or cGAS-STING signaling.

final_claims.statement: The Warburg effect and immune evasion are mechanistically coupled through VDAC gating — the same molecular investments (HK-II recruitment, cholesterol enrichment) that optimize glycolysis simultaneously prevent immune visibility.
final_claims.mechanism: Competitive allocation: HK-II bound to VDAC provides glycolytic substrate channeling while sterically preventing the oligomeric rearrangement needed for mtDNA-driven innate immune activation.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Finding tumors with high Warburg phenotype and high f_HKII that are nonetheless immune-hot with active cGAS-STING signaling.

final_claims.statement: Gate-restoring drugs (HK-II displacers + navitoclax-class Bcl-xL inhibitors) will synergize with anti-PD-1 specifically in immune-cold tumors with high f_HKII.
final_claims.mechanism: Forced VDAC oligomerization releases mtDNA, activates cGAS-STING, generates type-I interferon signaling that recruits T-cells, which checkpoint inhibitors then unleash.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Combination therapy showing no differential benefit in immune-cold vs immune-hot tumors stratified by VDAC state, or gate-restoration failing to increase TIL density.

final_claims.statement: f_HKII occupancy and Chol/CL ratio from tumor biopsies can serve as predictive biomarkers for immunotherapy response, with high values predicting resistance.
final_claims.mechanism: These cofactor parameters quantify gate-jamming intensity, which determines whether the tumor can generate the mtDNA-cGAS-STING signal necessary for immune recognition.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Retrospective analysis of immunotherapy cohorts showing no correlation between VDAC cofactor metrics and response rates. ───

final_claims.statement: Gate-jamming (high f_HKII, f_BclxL, Chol/CL) predicts immune-cold tumors by preventing VDAC1 oligomerization and mtDNA-cGAS-STING activation.
final_claims.mechanism: VDAC1 oligomerization is required for mtDNA release; jamming factors stabilize monomeric VDAC1, blocking cGAS-STING.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Tumors with high gate-jamming but high cGAS-STING activity, or low gate-jamming but immune-cold phenotypes.

final_claims.statement: Pharmacological gate-restoration (HK-II displacement + Bcl-xL inhibition) will convert immune-cold tumors to immune-hot and synergize with checkpoint inhibitors.
final_claims.mechanism: Forced VDAC1 oligomerization → mtDNA leak → cGAS-STING activation → T-cell infiltration; checkpoint inhibitors amplify existing immune responses.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Gate-restoration failing to increase cGAS-STING activity or T-cell infiltration in immune-cold tumors, or lack of synergy with checkpoint inhibitors.

final_claims.statement: f_HKII occupancy or Chol/CL ratio in tumor biopsies can predict immunotherapy response.
final_claims.mechanism: High gate-jamming metrics correlate with suppressed cGAS-STING and poor checkpoint inhibitor efficacy.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Retrospective/prospective studies showing no correlation between gate-jamming metrics and immunotherapy response.

final_claims.statement: Warburg metabolism (high glycolysis) is causally linked to immune evasion via gate-jamming.
final_claims.mechanism: Glycolytic flux increases HK-II binding to VDAC1, stabilizing the gate-jammed state and suppressing mtDNA leak.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Metabolically active tumors with low gate-jamming or immune-hot phenotypes, or non-glycolytic tumors with high gate-jamming.

final_claims.statement: Checkpoint inhibitors alone are ineffective in gate-jammed tumors due to lack of pre-existing immune visibility.
final_claims.mechanism: PD-1/PD-L1 blockade requires antigen presentation and T-cell priming; gate-jammed tumors lack cGAS-STING-driven immune activation.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Gate-jammed tumors responding to checkpoint inhibitors without prior gate-restoration. --- ───

final_claims.statement: Gate-jamming (high f_HKII/f_BclxL/Chol/CL) predicts immune-cold tumors by blocking VDAC1 oligomerization and mtDNA-cGAS-STING.
final_claims.mechanism: HKII/BclxL/Chol stabilize closed VDAC1 conformations, preventing Bax/Bak-induced oligomers that leak mtDNA to activate innate immunity.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Biopsies showing high f_HKII/Chol-CL in immune-hot (high T-cell/PDL1) tumors.

final_claims.statement: Pharmacological gate-restoration (HKII displacement + BclxL inhibition) can convert immune-cold to hot tumors via forced VDAC oligomerization/mtDNA release.
final_claims.mechanism: Displacing stabilizers allows pro-apoptotic pores to oligomerize VDAC1, leaking mtDNA to trigger cGAS-STING independently of adaptive immunity.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vivo cold-tumor models where combo fails to ↑ STING signaling/TIL infiltration.

final_claims.statement: Gate-restoration + checkpoint inhibitors synergize specifically in immune-cold tumors, resolving PD1/PDL1 paradox.
final_claims.mechanism: Gate-drugs provide initial cGAS-STING "visibility" signal absent in jammed/cold tumors, amplifying PD1 blockade effects.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Clinical trials showing no added benefit of combo vs checkpoint alone in cold tumors.

final_claims.statement: f_HKII occupancy or Chol/CL ratio from biopsies predicts poor immunotherapy response.
final_claims.mechanism: Cofactor equation links high jamming fractions to absent cGAS-STING, stratifying cold tumors unresponsive to checkpoint amplification.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Patient cohorts with high f_HKII/Chol-CL but high IO response rates.

final_claims.statement: High Warburg/glycolysis (↑ HKII recruitment) jams VDAC gate, explaining immune-coldness in metabolically active tumors.
final_claims.mechanism: Glycolytic flux ↑ f_HKII-VDAC binding per cofactor equation, stabilizing gate to block oligomerization/mtDNA leak.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Glycolytic tumors with low f_HKII but immune-cold profile. ───

final_claims.statement: High VDAC1 occupancy by Hexokinase-II (f_HKII) and/or a high membrane Chol/CL ratio in tumor biopsies are strong predictive biomarkers for primary resistance to PD-1/PD-L1 checkpoint inhibitors.
final_claims.mechanism: These gate-jamming conditions prevent VDAC1 oligomerization, blocking the release of mitochondrial dsDNA required to activate the cGAS-STING pathway, thus rendering the tumor immunologically "invisible."
final_claims.falsifiable_by: A multi-center patient cohort study showing no significant correlation between pre-treatment f_HKII or Chol/CL levels and lack of response to anti-PD-1 therapy.

final_claims.statement: Pharmacological VDAC1 gate-restoration will synergize with checkpoint inhibitors, primarily by converting non-responders into responders.
final_claims.mechanism: Gate-restoring drugs force VDAC1 oligomerization and mtDNA release, initiating cGAS-STING signaling that recruits T-cells to the tumor, creating the inflammatory context required for a checkpoint inhibitor to function effectively.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Preclinical studies in syngeneic immune-cold mouse tumor models where combination therapy with a gate-restoring drug and anti-PD-1 fails to show efficacy greater than the sum of the individual agents.

final_claims.statement: The Warburg effect is a dual-purpose adaptation, providing metabolic support for proliferation while actively enforcing immune evasion through VDAC1 gate-jamming.
final_claims.mechanism: The high glycolytic flux required for rapid growth necessitates high levels of mitochondrial-bound HK-II, which provides a direct, built-in mechanism to suppress innate immune detection by stabilizing VDAC1.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Identification of a cancer type that exhibits a strong Warburg phenotype but maintains a robustly immune-hot microenvironment due to active cGAS-STING signaling independent of VDAC1 state. ───

final_claims.statement: High fractional occupancy of VDAC1 by HK-II and Bcl-xL, plus a high Chol/CL ratio, predicts immune-cold tumors by preventing VDAC1 oligomerization and mtDNA-driven cGAS-STING activation.
final_claims.mechanism: These cofactors stabilize the VDAC1 closed state, physically blocking pore oligomerization required for mtDNA release, thereby silencing a key innate immune signal.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Finding immune-hot tumors with demonstrably high HK-II/VDAC1 binding and high mitochondrial cholesterol, or immune-cold tumors with low cofactor occupancy and no mtDNA in cytosol.

final_claims.statement: Pharmacological displacement of HK-II and inhibition of Bcl-xL will synergize with PD-1/PD-L1 blockade specifically in immune-cold tumors, but not in already immune-hot tumors.
final_claims.mechanism: Gate-restoring drugs induce VDAC1 oligomerization and mtDNA leak, initiating innate immune recognition (creating "signal 1"), which checkpoint inhibitors can then amplify by removing T-cell inhibition.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: A clinical trial showing no added benefit of a VDAC1 gate-restorer + anti-PD1 in immune-cold tumors versus anti-PD1 alone.

final_claims.statement: The f_HKII (HK-II occupancy) or Chol/CL ratio from tumor biopsies can serve as a predictive biomarker for intrinsic resistance to checkpoint inhibitor monotherapy.
final_claims.mechanism: These metrics directly report on the probability of VDAC1 oligomerization and thus the tumor's baseline ability to activate cGAS-STING, which is prerequisite for checkpoint inhibitor efficacy.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: A prospective study showing no correlation between these measured ratios and objective response rate to anti-PD1/PD-L1.

final_claims.statement: The Warburg effect promotes immune evasion not only via lactate but also by increasing HK-II binding to VDAC1, directly jamming the mtDNA leak pathway.
final_claims.mechanism: High glycolytic flux increases mitochondrial HK-II binding, which stabilizes VDAC1 in a closed, non-oligomerizing state, providing a direct metabolic link between glycolysis and immune invisibility.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that Warburg-active tumors with genetically severed HK-II-VDAC1 binding remain immune-cold. ───
